description: Fundamental concepts of APIs: HTTP methods, status codes, headers, and endpoints.

slides.title: What is an API?
slides.content:
# Application Programming Interface üîå

A mechanism that enables two software components to communicate with each other using a set of definitions and protocols.

Like a waiter in a restaurant: takes your order (request), goes to the kitchen (server), and brings back food (response).

slides.title: HTTP Methods
slides.content:
# The Verbs üó£Ô∏è

How we interact with resources.

- **GET:** Retrieve data.
- **POST:** Create new data.
- **PUT:** Update existing data (Full).
- **PATCH:** Update existing data (Partial).
- **DELETE:** Remove data.

slides.title: Endpoints
slides.content:
# The Address üìç

Where the resource lives.

URL (Uniform Resource Locator).

`https://api.site.com/users/123`

- `https` protocol
- `api.site.com` host
- `/users/123` path

slides.title: Status Codes (2xx)
slides.content:
# Success ‚úÖ

- **200 OK:** Everything worked.
- **201 Created:** New resource created (often after POST).
- **204 No Content:** Success, but nothing to return (often after DELETE).

slides.title: Method Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: Which HTTP method is best suited for CREATING a new resource?

slides.title: Status Codes (4xx)
slides.content:
# Client Error ‚õî

- **400 Bad Request:** Invalid input.
- **401 Unauthorized:** Who are you? (Login needed).
- **403 Forbidden:** I know you, but you can't come in (Permissions).
- **404 Not Found:** Use map.

slides.title: Status Codes (5xx)
slides.content:
# Server Error üî•

- **500 Internal Server Error:** Server crashed or bug in code.
- **502 Bad Gateway:** Upstream server failed.
- **503 Service Unavailable:** Maintenance or overload.

slides.title: Headers
slides.content:
# Metadata üè∑Ô∏è

Key-value pairs sent with request/response.

- `Content-Type: application/json` (What acts format is this?)
- `Authorization: Bearer <token>` (Credentials)
- `User-Agent: Chrome` (Who am I?)

slides.title: Request Body
slides.content:
# The Payload üì¶

Data sent *to* the server (usually with POST/PUT).

Common format: JSON.

```json
{
  "username": "jdoe",
  "email": "john@example.com"
}
```

slides.title: Response Body
slides.content:
# The Answer üìÑ

Data sent *back* from the server.

Also usually JSON.

```json
{
  "id": 101,
  "status": "created"
}
```

slides.title: Code Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: What status code represents 'Page Not Found'?

slides.title: Code Example
slides.content:
# Raw Request üíª

<!-- FULL_CODE_START
POST /api/users HTTP/1.1
Host: example.com
Content-Type: application/json
Authorization: Bearer xyz123

{
  "name": "Alice",
  "role": "admin"
}
FULL_CODE_END -->

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Recap: APIs üéì

Communication.

- **Methods:** GET, POST, PUT, DELETE.
- **Codes:** 200 (OK), 404 (Missing), 500 (Broken).
- **Headers:** Metadata like Auth.
- **Endpoints:** The URL.
